talk.start.para: a asked the Minister for Housing, upon notice -

item.para: What has been the total amount granted to each of the States and Territories under the Commonwealth and States Housing Agreement since 1945, and what has been the total amount of interest charged to each?
What is the interest rate charged?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows -

item.para: The Commonwealth-State Housing Agreements provide for advances from the Commonwealth to the States, but not to the Territories. The following are total advances from the Commonwealth to the States and total interest paid by the States to the Commonwealth, under the Agreements, from 1945 to 30th June 1964 -

Under the 1945 Agreement the maximum interest rate chargeable to the States was to be the long-term bond rate at the time each advance was made, but the rate actually charged on the advances remained at 3 per cent. per annum when the long-term bond rate rose to 5 per cent. per annum. Under the 1956 Agreement, the interest rate chargeable, to the States was to be determined, according to a formula, at¾ to 1 per cent. below the long-term bond rate at the time each advance was made. However, the interest rates actually charged during the term of the Agreement were held at a full 1 per cent, per annum less than the current long-term bond rate. Under the 1961 Agreement, which is operative until 30th June 1966, the interest rate chargeable to the States has been fixed, as provided in the Agreement, at 1 per cent, per annum below the long-term bond rale at the time each advance was made. The actual interest rates charged to the States since 1st July 1956 were -

talk.start.para: y asked the Minister representing the Minister for Civil Aviation, upon notice -

item.para: ls the examination for the issue of an Airline Pilots Transport Licence known as the A.T.P. Examination?
Are the subjects for examination, navigation, meteorology and flight planning?
Arc the papers set by the Department of Civil Aviation?
Arc the examinations held twice yearly: if so, in what months are they held?
Were the examinations at one time held three times yearly; if so, when were they reduced in number?
Has the failure rate increased since the reduction in the number of examinations each year?
rs it a fact that the pass rate in navigation and flight planning is below 10 per cent, in both subjects?
Docs the Department release pass rates; if not, why not?
Is it a fact that examination questions are in book form?
Are answers recorded in the book with the result that candidates cannot keep questions and past papers for reference and study?
Is it a fact that coaching for the examination is available at the technical college, but as questions are not of a consistent pattern, the coaching staff is in the dark as to what to teach?
Can he say whether similar examinations held overseas are easier?
Is there a big reserve of experienced pilots

question.para: Available in Australia to airline companies who need not pay salaries due to employees who are qualified to become captains?

item.para: Is it a fact that a first officer, who the Department considers is not capable of being in charge of an aircraft, must take charge and be responsible for safety of passengers if the captain becomes ill?

Is it a fact that Australian first officers with thousands of hours flying time are deprived by the Department of promotion while overseas pilots, who have sat for easier examinations are imported and employed?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Civil Aviation has supplied the following answers -

item.para: Yes.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes. In February and November.
Yes. In February, June and October.
No. There has been significant change in the pass rate since the number of examinations per year has been reduced.
No. It is above this figure in both subjects.
The Department has not released pass rates in the past because the need to do so has not been apparent.
Yes. Book form examinations were introduced because they were an improvement in the format of the examination paper from the view point of the candidate.

Yes. Papers are made available to ground training organisations immediately after the conclusion of examinations and are available at the Department's Regional Offices for general distribution to individuals within approximately seven days of the date of the examination.

Coaching for these examinations is provided by several ground training organisations, some of which are technical colleges. Questions naturally vary from examination to examination but are all within the syllabus for the examinations published in the Air Navigation Orders. Immediately after each examination, the Department in the Post Examination Review Panel meets representatives of the ground training organisations, operators and the Australian Federation of Air Pilots to discuss in detail each examination paper. At these meetings, representatives are given the opportunity of commenting on questions and obtaining other information and guidance regarding the coverage of the syllabus in the examination papers.

Similar examinations overseas are no easier than those in Australia. In the United Kingdom the examinations for the issue of similar licences are more difficult and pilots holding Australian licences are required to undertake additional theory examinations to obtain an equivalent licence in the United Kingdom. 1.3. There is, in fact, a shortage of pilots who are qualified to become captains in Australia at the moment.

A first officer is required to achieve a standard which gives reasonable assurance that a flight can be terminated safely in the event of the captain becoming ill. lt does not give assurance that this class of pilot could command the aircraft on a regular basis and still maintain the high levels of safely required for regular operations. The statistical probability of a first officer having to perform the role of captain in an emergency is sufficiently remote as to make completely acceptable a standard less than that required of captains.

No. The Department will not grant Australian pilot licences to any pilot who cannot establish that he has reached the standard required. Exemption from theory examinations is given only to the holders of overseas licences issued by authorities whose standards have been verified as being equal to or higher than Australian standards.

talk.start.para: d asked the Minister for Housing, upon notice -

quote.para: What amount of deposit is required from applicants for housing assistance through housing commissions or trusts in the various States?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honorable member's question is as follows -

quote.para: The minimum deposit required by the housing authority in each State for the purchase of houses built with funds provided under the CommonwealthState Housing Agreement is -

subdebate.1.para: In addition, the South Australian Housing Trust and the State Housing Commission in Western Australia build houses for sale with funds provided from sources other than the CommonwealthState Housing Agreement. In South Australia the minimum deposit for these houses is £200 and in Western Australia usually not less than £100.
